title: SpaceX Scrubs Launch of Crew-10 Astronauts for NASA to the I.S.S.
description: An issue with a ground system that supports the Falcon 9 rocket led to a postponement of at least one day of the latest rotation of space station crews.
author: Kenneth Chang
excerpt: An issue with a ground system that supports the Falcon 9 rocket led to a postponement of at least one day of the latest rotation of space station crews.

An issue with a ground system that supports the Falcon 9 rocket led to a postponement of at least one day of the latest rotation of space station crews.

March 12, 2025Updated 7:15 p.m. ET

Four astronauts will have to wait at least one more day to the International Space Station on Wednesday night.

This otherwise routine rotation of crew on the space station is garnering extra attention because it will at last allow the return to Earth of Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, two NASA astronauts whose brief scheduled visit to the space station last June was unexpectedly stretched to more than nine months.

The scrub of the flight, which occurred less than 45 minutes before the scheduled liftoff, means Mr. Wilmore and Ms. Williams’ stay in orbit will also be extended at least one more day. During the countdown, SpaceX encountered a hydraulic issue with a clamp arm that holds onto the Falcon 9 rocket before it launches.

If the issue can be fixed quickly, SpaceX could try again on Thursday. There is another launch opportunity on Friday.

Here’s other information about the mission, which is named Crew-10 because it is the 10th such mission by SpaceX ferrying crew to and from the space station.

Who is going to space on Crew-10?

Anne McClain of NASA is the commander of Crew-10, and Nichole Ayers of NASA is the pilot. The other two crew members are Takuya Onishi of JAXA, the Japanese space agency, and Kirill Peskov of Roscosmos, the Russian space agency.
